subject: Science
title: How Small Are Atoms Really?
description: Learn How Small Are Atoms Really? in one minute.

hook.text: A single drop of water contains more atoms than there are stars in the observable universe.

buildup.text: An atom is about 0.1 nanometers wide. A human hair is 800,000 atoms thick.

discovery.text: You could line up 10 million atoms across a single millimeter.

twist.text: Atoms are so small that no optical microscope can see them. Light waves are too big.

climax.text: We finally saw individual atoms in 1970 using electron microscopes.

punchline.text: A drop of water has more atoms than stars you can see. Size is relative.

quiz.question: Why can't optical microscopes see atoms?
options: Light wavelengths are larger than atoms
Atoms move too fast to photograph
